content: once inserted into another network, the “same” philosopheme is no longer the same > inversely, “unique and original (inédits)” philosophemes, if there are any, once they enter network of inherited philosophemes, they’re affected over their whole surface and under every angle > the very project of rigorous criteria for judging philosophical specificity, which we are nowhere near disposing of, belongs to a set of conditions (un ensemble)—that remains to be thought

content: Kant allies pure morality w/ empirical culturalism in critique of pure judgments of taste

content: economimesis: to show the link between oikonomia and mimesis ——economy not yet defined as general or restricted, their relation must be neither of identity nor contradiction, must be other

content: a politics (a political economy) acts upon his discourse
linkedContent: a politics (a political economy) acts upon his discourse

content: Kant’s remarks on mimesis set forth by remarks on salary?: 1) difference btwn free (freie) art and mercenary art (Lohnkunst) 2) Fine-Arts must occupy the mind w/out end (but), w/out salary
linkedContent: Kant’s remarks on mimesis set forth by remarks on salary?: 1) difference btwn free (freie) art and mercenary art (Lohnkunst) 2) Fine-Arts must occupy the mind w/out end (but), w/out salary

content: proportional analogy btwn oppositions dissolves them, but first the oppositions must be produced, and there’s [almost?] always a regular hierarchy
linkedContent: proportional analogy btwn oppositions dissolves them, but first the oppositions must be produced, and there’s [almost?] always a regular hierarchy

content: for Kant, art is originally not nature (mechanical necessity) but freedom; however, when nature assigns its rules to genius, it folds itself into art: so art no longer mimics nature, nature is the secret resource of mimicry
linkedContent: for Kant, art is originally not nature (mechanical necessity) but freedom; however, when nature assigns its rules to genius, it folds itself into art: so art no longer mimics nature, nature is the secret resource of mimicry

content: for Kant, nature speaks to us through its beautiful forms, one can read the “ciphered language (Chiffreschrift),” nature’s signature as art productions
linkedContent: for Kant, nature speaks to us through its beautiful forms, one can read the “ciphered language (Chiffreschrift),” nature’s signature as art productions

content: even if this stance is opposed to Hegel [only art is beautiful], analogy btwn art and nature always provides a principle of reconciliation
linkedContent: even if this stance is opposed to Hegel [only art is beautiful], analogy btwn art and nature always provides a principle of reconciliation

content: for Kant, difference btwn free, liberal art and mercenary art is the difference btwn play/work
linkedContent: for Kant, difference btwn free, liberal art and mercenary art is the difference btwn play/work

content: the anthropology of art as freedom, as beyond nature, raises man up, but the “ruse and naiveté” of economimesis: in order to save this absolute privilege of human emergence (art, freedom, language), of grounding it in absolute naturalism [?], man’s production (anthropological domesticity) has to be renaturalized > differentiation effaced into opposition (i.e. bees have no art)
linkedContent: the anthropology of art as freedom, as beyond nature, raises man up, but the “ruse and naiveté” of economimesis: in order to save this absolute privilege of human emergence (art, freedom, language), of grounding it in absolute naturalism [?], man’s production (anthropological domesticity) has to be renaturalized > differentiation effaced into opposition (i.e. bees have no art)

content: genius of poetry, the highest of Fine-Arts: full expression of productive imagination receives its rules from Nature, thus breaking from mimesis > free unfolding-refolding of physis
linkedContent: genius of poetry, the highest of Fine-Arts: full expression of productive imagination receives its rules from Nature, thus breaking from mimesis > free unfolding-refolding of physis

content: Derrida mentions a tightrope walker in Kant, encourages “anyone” to take the plunge (put in something of himself): Kant, Nietzsche, Genet
linkedContent: Derrida mentions a tightrope walker in Kant, encourages “anyone” to take the plunge (put in something of himself): Kant, Nietzsche, Genet

content: for Kant, art is a power, aptitude, property, destiny of man (Geschicklichkeit des Menschen), and is distinguished from science (where to know is to know how to do, to be able to)
linkedContent: for Kant, art is a power, aptitude, property, destiny of man (Geschicklichkeit des Menschen), and is distinguished from science (where to know is to know how to do, to be able to)

content: art can’t enter into circle of commerce, must be free, not a craft (Handwerk), thus mercenary art is lower, is like the work of bees, is not the play of imagination, but a fixed program w/out reason
linkedContent: art can’t enter into circle of commerce, must be free, not a craft (Handwerk), thus mercenary art is lower, is like the work of bees, is not the play of imagination, but a fixed program w/out reason

content: [acc. Kant] free, liberal art: 1) play, not salaried work, free man (artist) is not homo oeconomicus, is more human 2) free, liberal art can utilize mercenary art w/out being contaminated by it 3) a productive, spontaneous, not reproductive (mimetic) imagination
linkedContent: [acc. Kant] free, liberal art: 1) play, not salaried work, free man (artist) is not homo oeconomicus, is more human 2) free, liberal art can utilize mercenary art w/out being contaminated by it 3) a productive, spontaneous, not reproductive (mimetic) imagination

content: liberal, free art relates to mercenary art as mind to body; free art enjoys itself but still incurs the unenjoyable incursions, lexical rules etc., of mercenary art; art still requires pedagogy
linkedContent: liberal, free art relates to mercenary art as mind to body; free art enjoys itself but still incurs the unenjoyable incursions, lexical rules etc., of mercenary art; art still requires pedagogy

content: why call them Fine-Arts (Beaux-Arts)? why not just call the product beautiful: because the product must still be implicated by its signature, beauty is ascribed to the passage btwn production/product; Fine-Arts: always of the frame & signature
linkedContent: why call them Fine-Arts (Beaux-Arts)? why not just call the product beautiful: because the product must still be implicated by its signature, beauty is ascribed to the passage btwn production/product; Fine-Arts: always of the frame & signature

content: essence, proper, oikos of man is to take pleasure in reflection w/out concept, w/out enjoyment, i.e. non-exhangable productivity: non-exchangeable in terms of sensible objects or signs of sensible objects (money), and in terms of enjoyment (neither use nor exchange value)
linkedContent: essence, proper, oikos of man is to take pleasure in reflection w/out concept, w/out enjoyment, i.e. non-exhangable productivity: non-exchangeable in terms of sensible objects or signs of sensible objects (money), and in terms of enjoyment (neither use nor exchange value)

content: a divine teleology secures the political economy of Fine-Arts
linkedContent: a divine teleology secures the political economy of Fine-Arts

content: for Kant, science is not art, has no beauty in it, because no pleasure can be taken in it
linkedContent: for Kant, science is not art, has no beauty in it, because no pleasure can be taken in it

content: yet, in his Introduction, he claims that in an immemorial past, pleasure could not be separated from knowledge, so the Witz (bon mot), the only scientific pleasure, carries this repressed past in it
linkedContent: yet, in his Introduction, he claims that in an immemorial past, pleasure could not be separated from knowledge, so the Witz (bon mot), the only scientific pleasure, carries this repressed past in it

content: Kant distinguishes agreeable arts from Fine-Arts, the former aims at enjoyment (jouissance, Genuss), the latter dispenses w/ concept (ohne Zweck) and enjoyment, but seeks pleasure (Lust)
linkedContent: Kant distinguishes agreeable arts from Fine-Arts, the former aims at enjoyment (jouissance, Genuss), the latter dispenses w/ concept (ohne Zweck) and enjoyment, but seeks pleasure (Lust)

content: and yet, in this pure oikos, man must seem als ob (as if) it were a product of nature, must resemble nature while not depending on it: the artist thus imitates the very act of nature itself; man as artist-god, a commerce between divine artist and man, this commerce is a mimesis, identification, mask on stage, a “true” mimesis btwn subjects not things that critiques servility of imitation > “true” mimesis: that of 2 productions, 2 freedoms [man & God/nature]
linkedContent: and yet, in this pure oikos, man must seem als ob (as if) it were a product of nature, must resemble nature while not depending on it: the artist thus imitates the very act of nature itself; man as artist-god, a commerce between divine artist and man, this commerce is a mimesis, identification, mask on stage, a “true” mimesis btwn subjects not things that critiques servility of imitation > “true” mimesis: that of 2 productions, 2 freedoms [man & God/nature]

content: w/ the figure of the innate genius, nature produces the arts, is freedom itself
linkedContent: w/ the figure of the innate genius, nature produces the arts, is freedom itself

content: God has given himself to be seen in a spectacle, as if he masked/showed himself: an immense liberality which can only give itself to itself to be consumed [how can man’s freedom mimic God’s: by not resembling it?]
linkedContent: God has given himself to be seen in a spectacle, as if he masked/showed himself: an immense liberality which can only give itself to itself to be consumed [how can man’s freedom mimic God’s: by not resembling it?]

content: for Aristotle, imitation is unique to man, belongs to essential definition of man, man takes pleasure in it, it is from it he learns his first knowledge
linkedContent: for Aristotle, imitation is unique to man, belongs to essential definition of man, man takes pleasure in it, it is from it he learns his first knowledge

content: for Kant, imitation is aping (singerie), yet w/ the genius he conceives an imitation of divine freedom, distinguishing [briefly] between a good imitation and a bad copy: Nachahmung, Nachtmachung ——genius capitalizes freedom, in same gesture naturalizes economimesis
linkedContent: for Kant, imitation is aping (singerie), yet w/ the genius he conceives an imitation of divine freedom, distinguishing [briefly] between a good imitation and a bad copy: Nachahmung, Nachtmachung ——genius capitalizes freedom, in same gesture naturalizes economimesis

content: for Kant, genius capitalizes freedom while naturalizing economimesis
linkedContent: for Kant, genius capitalizes freedom while naturalizing economimesis

content: “naturalization of political economy subordinates the production and the commerce of art to a transeconomy,” poet supersedes the circular, rises above restricted economy: economimesis unfolds itself to infinity: “Kantism" passes into “Hegelianism”
linkedContent: “naturalization of political economy subordinates the production and the commerce of art to a transeconomy,” poet supersedes the circular, rises above restricted economy: economimesis unfolds itself to infinity: “Kantism" passes into “Hegelianism”

content: poetic gift is an add-on (un en-plus), given as a power to give by God so that, via the poet, this supplementary surplus value can return to the infinite source, the poet breaks from the circular economy, that is the passage to the infinite: passage of infinity btwn gift/debt

content: analogy of God and poet proceeds from and returns to logos, source as mouth and outlet (embouchure)
linkedContent: analogy of God and poet proceeds from and returns to logos, source as mouth and outlet (embouchure)

content: the fold of mimesis at origin of pure productivity: a gift for itself (pour soi) of God who makes a present of himself to himself
linkedContent: the fold of mimesis at origin of pure productivity: a gift for itself (pour soi) of God who makes a present of himself to himself

content: nature dictates to the poet and is the product
linkedContent: nature dictates to the poet and is the product

content: Hegel critiques Kant’s 3rd Critique for staying at the level of “you must” > he very well evinces the moral order that sustains the aesthetic one

content: when analogy is the rule (nature speaks, God speaks, highest poet speaks): “ça veut dire que ça veut dire et que ça dit que ça veut dire que ça veut et que ça veut ce que ça veut par exemple”
linkedContent: when analogy is the rule (nature speaks, God speaks, highest poet speaks): “ça veut dire que ça veut dire et que ça dit que ça veut dire que ça veut et que ça veut ce que ça veut par exemple”

linkedContent: analogy as rule btwn rule of art & moral rule > articulated play of analogy is subject to law of supplementarity: we admire nature [beauty] w/out the [moral] purpose appearing to us

content: [how the purposelessness of beauty becomes the teleology of humanity]
linkedContent: [how the purposelessness of beauty becomes the teleology of humanity]

content: for Kant, the purpose-lessness (le sans-fin) of the experience of beauty leads us inside ourselves, there’s an interiorizing suppléance, a slurping (suçotement), by which we find our moral destination w/in, consume w/in what we can’t consume outside; this inside purpose, teleology, is moral and analogously relates to natural harmony

linkedContent: analogy of God and poet proceeds from and returns to logos, source as mouth and outlet (embouchure)

content: [re: disinterested pleasure] a moral revenue drawn from a natural production w/out interest to us; one takes wealth w/out interest, the singular moral surplus value of sans—still, the trace (Spur) of a purpose in nature is what makes our stock in moral value rise
linkedContent: [re: disinterested pleasure] a moral revenue drawn from a natural production w/out interest to us; one takes wealth w/out interest, the singular moral surplus value of sans—still, the trace (Spur) of a purpose in nature is what makes our stock in moral value rise

linkedContent: for Kant, colors, which are generally adornments, are affiliated w/ moral qualities (i.e. red–sublimity, violet–tenderness)

linkedContent: for Kant, “meditation on a disinterested pleasure…provokes a moral interest in the beautiful” > interest taken in disinterestedness

content: Kant’s exemplorality, exemplary orality, the mouth—os as absolute of every analogon: mouth is the measure of taste, of good art, it’s also the measure of bad taste (consumptive taste): one expressive (emissive) the other vomitive (emitic) > 2 means of entering/leaving the mouth

content: if pure taste demands non-consumption, wouldn’t disgust (rejection) be origin of pure taste?
linkedContent: if pure taste demands non-consumption, wouldn’t disgust (rejection) be origin of pure taste?

content: poetry blows up finite limits of other arts, it presents the plenitude of thought (Gedankenfülle)

content: for Kant, poetry’s privilege is not just in the interiorizing structure of (mouth to ear) hearing oneself speak, but in sincerity, faithful adequation [its truth]; these values are not immediately moral > morality itself derives its value from full presence/full speech

content: for Kant, the “as if” of the poet (“as if” of nature) is better, sincerer, more loyal than the “as if” of the orator, who wears a mask, deceives, his “as if” is “machine-like”
linkedContent: for Kant, the “as if” of the poet (“as if” of nature) is better, sincerer, more loyal than the “as if” of the orator, who wears a mask, deceives, his “as if” is “machine-like”

content: for Kant, the mouth (from which comes the highest form of expression) is self-affecting
linkedContent: for Kant, the mouth (from which comes the highest form of expression) is self-affecting

content: Kant analogizes division of Fine-Arts w/ the mode of expression man possess in Sprechen (not w/out slight embarrassment) [this serves a teleological function]
linkedContent: Kant analogizes division of Fine-Arts w/ the mode of expression man possess in Sprechen (not w/out slight embarrassment) [this serves a teleological function]

content: rhetoric often compared to a machine, because there’s no intention inside > false life, empty symbolism of these sophistical tekhnai

content: for Kant, touch, sight, and hearing relate us to objects, to the outside, whereas smell and taste do not
linkedContent: for Kant, touch, sight, and hearing relate us to objects, to the outside, whereas smell and taste do not

content: hearing is privileged over sight due to its auto-affective freedom and spontaneity, but sight is the best sense for beauty because has the greatest remove from touch
linkedContent: hearing is privileged over sight due to its auto-affective freedom and spontaneity, but sight is the best sense for beauty because has the greatest remove from touch

content: for Kant, hearing is closest to freedom and spontaneity, one must use term hearing-oneself-speak (le s’entendre-parler) because the structure is auto-affective; the mute thus do not have reason, the mouth (indissociable from ear) is not simply an analogy of expression: it is the ground of analogy, regulates analogy, it is logos itself [necessary]

linkedContent: for Kant, hearing (w/ its allergy to prosthesis) distinguished from sight by its auto-affective structure, an internal sense, its “form” is time > not an anthropological but a psychological space

content: for Kant, sight is most noble sense, but hearing is least replaceable, most allergic to prosthesis, tolerates substitution badly, almost succeeds in resisting vicariousness: this is why the mute will never know concepts, they cannot access the universal signs

[can’t be named]

content: tautologically, vomit never lets itself be swallowed > thus causes itself to be vomited
linkedContent: tautologically, vomit never lets itself be swallowed > thus causes itself to be vomited

content: Kant: sublime occurs due to a momentary checking (Hemmung, an arrest), and its pleasure (admiration or respect) is a negative pleasure
linkedContent: Kant: sublime occurs due to a momentary checking (Hemmung, an arrest), and its pleasure (admiration or respect) is a negative pleasure

content: logo-phonocentric system doesn’t exclude a negative, negative is its business, it’s work, it excludes what can’t be digested, represented, eaten, irreducible heterogeneity: vomit
linkedContent: logo-phonocentric system doesn’t exclude a negative, negative is its business, it’s work, it excludes what can’t be digested, represented, eaten, irreducible heterogeneity: vomit

linkedContent: since, for Kant, the sensibility of the mouth also produces its ideality, vomit, for Derrida, will work on both levels as well

content: Derrida interested in vomit in relation to disgust, not vomiting (which can still be reappropriated as auto-affective)
linkedContent: Derrida interested in vomit in relation to disgust, not vomiting (which can still be reappropriated as auto-affective)

content: Derrida compares the work of mourning to the sublime, both allow negative pleasures to be reappropriated by economic calculation
linkedContent: Derrida compares the work of mourning to the sublime, both allow negative pleasures to be reappropriated by economic calculation

content: unrepresentable vomit gives too much enjoyment, suspends the suspension of non-consummation (which accompanies pleasure bound up w/ representation): it burns up all work as mourning work
linkedContent: unrepresentable vomit gives too much enjoyment, suspends the suspension of non-consummation (which accompanies pleasure bound up w/ representation): it burns up all work as mourning work

content: unrepresentable vomit violates our enjoyment, abolishes representative distance, prevents mourning, forces one to consume w/out chance of idealization
linkedContent: unrepresentable vomit violates our enjoyment, abolishes representative distance, prevents mourning, forces one to consume w/out chance of idealization

content: for Kant, that which is disgusting more unassimilable than evil, the ugly, the horrible (all of which can be made beautiful)
linkedContent: for Kant, that which is disgusting more unassimilable than evil, the ugly, the horrible (all of which can be made beautiful)

content: the ultimately disgusting is unrepresentable, l’exclu absolu, if one could name or represent it, it could enter auto-affective circle of master/reappropriation > must be insensible too (unnameable, un-intelligible), the absolute other of the system [Derrida compares this structure to that of the colossal]
linkedContent: the ultimately disgusting is unrepresentable, l’exclu absolu, if one could name or represent it, it could enter auto-affective circle of master/reappropriation > must be insensible too (unnameable, un-intelligible), the absolute other of the system [Derrida compares this structure to that of the colossal]

content: what is absolutely foreclosed from Kant’s system is not vomit but possibility of vicariousness of vomit, of its replacement by anything else: something that would undo the hierarchizing authority of logocentric analogy—its power of identification > i.e. the “in the place of,” replacement that has no proper place, no return: [the] in place of prosthesis —— w/in logocentric system (w/in the name), one simply can’t name what’s outside it, to say it would be to eat it—or, what is no longer absolutely different—to vomit it

content: to say that the other of the system of taste is distaste (disgust) is tautological, yes > Derrida wonders whether the tautological structure (that of logos as self-same-identity) is the very form of what the exclusion (of disgust) serves to construct

content: question “what is?”: offers a paregoric parergon, constructs framework to capture energy of unassimilable, it softens, remedies, w/ speech, consoles, exhorts w/ the word

content: vomit, the word, arrests the vicariousness of disgust, and thus is still an elixir for philosophy
